description:
During a summer camp, 15 children, 8 males and 7 females, find a grotto by the sea. Deep within they discover working computers and some electronic equipment, and later the owner, a man called Kokopelli. Kokopelli claimed to be a programmer working on a brand new game, in which a large robot has to defend the Earth against alien invasions. He persuades the children to test the game and sign a contract. All but one of them signs, barely a moment later they mysteriously awaken on the shore believing what happened was just a dream.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Alternate Universe
tags.description: Features multiple alternate universes in the same series.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Denpa
tags.description: Works that feature themes of social dissociation, delusions, and other issues like suicide, bullying, self-isolation, paranoia, and technological necessity in daily lives. Classic iconography: telephone poles, rooftops, and trains.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Death Game
tags.description: Features characters participating in a game, where failure results in death.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Yakuza
tags.description: Centered around Japanese organised crime syndicates.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Age Gap
tags.description: Prominently features romantic relations between people with a significant age difference.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

node.description: [Twitter](https://twitter.com/mohiro_kitoh)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/松本憲生)

Originating from Tatsunoko's animators training institute, where he met [Atsushi Wakabayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/105805/). Though primarily an action animator, he’s demonstrated impressive range elsewhere like in his scenes for [Haibane Renmei](https://anilist.co/anime/387/) and [Kaguya-hime](https://anilist.co/anime/16664/). He has the reputation of a fast and disciplined worker. [Toshiyuki Inoue](https://anilist.co/staff/103724/) said that he must have a “secret” for producing such a large volume of superb cuts.

Though one of his earliest assignments was as an in-betweens checker for [Akira](https://anilist.co/anime/47/), his first major job was on [Ranma ½](https://anilist.co/anime/210/), working under the director of the series, [Kazuhiro Furuhashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100655/). He would collaborate with Furuhashi again on Rurouni Kenshin, [You’re Under Arrest](https://anilist.co/anime/1577/), and [Hunter x Hunter](https://anilist.co/anime/136/). Around this time Matsumoto was also mentored by [Tomohiro Hirata](https://anilist.co/staff/122071/) on [Irresponsible Captain Tylor](https://anilist.co/anime/569/).

Matsumoto’s character animation is loose and full of smears, often looking like featureless masses in individual frames. He draws smoke without highlights, a tendency that earned the nickname “Norio smoke” and has been imitated by animators like [Shingo Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/114914/) and [Kenichi Kutsuna](https://anilist.co/staff/116007/). He occasionally storyboards his own scenes as he did for the 12th episode of [Birdy Decode:02](https://anilist.co/anime/5074/), the [third Naruto movie](https://anilist.co/anime/2144/), and episodes 31 & 85 of [Rurouni Kenshin](https://anilist.co/anime/45/). Prefers battles that take place in wide-open spaces with lots of forward momentum and background movement. Influenced by [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/) and [Takashi Nakamura](https://anilist.co/staff/102031/), and has adapted elements of their approach for a wider audience.

Whenever he serves as animation director on an episode, he does a lot of the key animation work himself. He also soloed the 7th episode of [Eat-Man](https://anilist.co/anime/1704/) and the [Kuragehime](https://anilist.co/anime/8129/) ED. He failed attempting to solo the 39th episode of You’re Under Arrest, and requested his name not be on the telop despite animating the vast majority of the episode.

Famous for his work on the [Naruto](https://anilist.co/anime/20/) franchise, in which he often collaborated with Atsushi Wakabayashi.

As a well known animator with a wide network of connections, he regularly helps and receives help from his friends.

(Source: Animators Wiki)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/石川智晶) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiaki_Ishikawa)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/229166670/)

After graduating from the Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering at Fukuoka University, he joined the animation studio [Shaft](https://anilist.co/studio/44/). There his first work as an in-betweener was on [Hiatari Ryoukou!](https://anilist.co/anime/729/). Afterwards, he went freelance and worked on films such as [Akira](https://anilist.co/anime/47/) and [Kiki's Delivery Service](https://anilist.co/anime/512/) before debuting as a key animator on [Lupin III: Bye Bye, Lady Liberty](https://anilist.co/anime/1415/) in 1989.

Him working on [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/)'s films as an animator led to him being selected as a director for [The Cat Returns](https://anilist.co/anime/597/). A movie which remains as one of his most noted works today. In 2007, he directed his first TV series, [Bokurano](https://anilist.co/anime/1690/).

[Twitter](https://x.com/hira0takayuk1)

He graduated from Osaka's Designer College and started his career at [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) as a production assistant, later making the transition to storyboarder and episode director with [Texhnolyze](https://anilist.co/anime/26/). During his time at Madhouse he served as Assistant Director to [Satoshi Kon](https://anilist.co/staff/99580/Satoshi-Kon) on [Paranoia Agent](https://anilist.co/anime/323/Paranoia-Agent/) and was greatly influenced by him, regarding him as his mentor. Shortly after leaving Madhouse he joined [Ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/ufotable), where he worked for several years and made his proper directorial debut with [Kara no Kyoukai 5](https://anilist.co/anime/4282/). 

He left Ufotable in 2016 and he's been freelance since, returning to the company only to direct the opening for the video game Shin Megami Tensei: Strange Journey. 

Him and [Tetsurou Araki](https://anilist.co/staff/100088/) are really close friends since their days at Madhouse. They run a column called *Bariuta no ai wo shiritai!!* published in the Animage monthly magazine. 

He is married to color designer [Emi Chiba](https://anilist.co/staff/103075/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/235154812) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/30949)

Started out as amateur gif animator before turning professional. He initially failed an examination test for [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) but was later scouted by the late [Osamu Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100406/) for [Beck](https://anilist.co/anime/57/). There he met noted animators [Norio Matsumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/100991/) and [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/), the former which he would work with on numerous occasions afterwards.

His breakthrough as an animator was on [Noein](https://anilist.co/anime/584/), a series directed by [Kazuki Akane](https://anilist.co/staff/102416/). The 12th episode was highly regarded by animation fans and other animators for the given display by him and Matsumoto. He would later also serve as a character designer on [Birdy the Mighty: Decode](https://anilist.co/anime/3974/), another series directed by Akane.

His dedication for animation could also be seen on [The Girl Who Leapt Through Time](https://anilist.co/anime/2236/), for which he animated a minute-long scene of the main character running down a street. He went on the actual street in Tokyo to film himself for reference footage for the cut.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/明田川仁)

Affiliated with Magic Capsule, a recording studio led by his father [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062).

Yuji Nomi is a music composer/arranger, born in 1958 in Tokyo.   Started his music activities at several art gallery by making multiplex recorded music with a synthesizer for his friend's art performances. Coincidentally, those music were noticed by Ryuichi Sakamoto, then Nomi has released his LP, Oshare TV from MIDI record in 1986, under the supervision of Mr.Sakamoto. After then, joined making/arranging music for the films produced by Mr.Sakamoto such as Adventures of Milo and Otisi, Wings of Honneamise. Also joined as an orchestrator for The Last Emperor the film.   Having made film music for Whisper of The Heart (Mimi O Sumaseba) the film by Studio Ghibli in 1995, then he also made music for two short films by Miyao Hayazaki, Koro No Oosampo and Kujiratori, for the Ghibli Museum of Tokyo in 2001. And made Ghibli's film music again in Hiroyuki Morita's The Cat Returns (Neko No Ongaeshi).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/森久司)

In the beginning of his career he was known for his sharp and clear [Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)-esque action scenes. After a while he abandoned his sharp style and shifted to a more realistic style that was more in line with [Mitsuo Iso](https://anilist.co/staff/100151/). At the time, the industry was filled to the brim with Iso followers, but according to [Takashi Hashimoto](https://anilist.co/staff/118452/); "The only people who wholly pursued Iso's style in animation were me, Mori, and [Shuuichi Kaneko](https://anilist.co/staff/143068/)."

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenichi_0623) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/小西賢一)

Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/).

Noted for his work as a character designer on tiles such as [Tokyo Godfathers](https://anilist.co/anime/759/), [Bokurano](https://anilist.co/anime/1690/) and [Children of the Sea](https://anilist.co/anime/103221/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田繁美)

Founder and representative director of Atelier Musa.
_Note: Not to be confused with the [scriptwriter](https://anilist.co/staff/119169/)._
[Twitter](http://twitter.com/i/user/128364216)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/yama_ic)

Yamashita is one of the key figures of the "Web Generation," being among the first to be recruited within the industry not after formal training but after demonstrating his talent by posting animated gifs online.

His first time standing out of the crowd was on [Birdy the Mighty Decode](https://anilist.co/anime/3974/Birdy-the-Mighty-Decode/). His animation favors expression above all else, to the point characters often bend out of shape when exposed to extreme forces and speeds. 

Despite this he still has a keen eye for delicate and realistic character animation, inspired by the likes of [Norio Matsumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/100991/Norio-Matsumoto), as demonstrated on both EDs for Birdy the Mighty Decode and [Shinsekai yori](https://anilist.co/anime/13125/From-the-New-World/) where he handled all aspects of the animation production. 

He is also adept in post production work, often handling the photography, coloring and even CG in his own works.
[Website](http://coosun.fc2web.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/coosun)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田繁美)

Founder and representative director of Atelier Musa.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/katsu_nak)

Affiliated with Sound Box.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Kali108Lilith)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kawasak54965532)

Hiroyuki Kawasaki is a screenwriter and novelist.
He is a member of Writers Guild of Japan.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/erkin_kawabata)

Known for his unique episodes on [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/)’s shows, where he was often collaborating with [Shingo Natsume](https://anilist.co/staff/118928/). His storyboards are noted for their natural lighting, preference towards "ugly" and unrefined drawings, occasional use of fisheye perspective, and disturbing subject matter.

Fluent in Russian and has competed in the All-Japan Sambo Championships.
